ColCompleteNotes: missing parts of limbs and tail

NarNarrative: Box Tortoises have a hinged lower shell to give the animal more space, allowing both head and forelimbs to stretch out when feeding while still being able to close up tightly when needed. The first picture gives an idea of the very large aperture when the lid is open, and number three shows how tightly the box can close.

This tortoise is the same variety as in record S0506, but picture 2 shows the very intricate shell pattern that the younger ones sometimes have. Picture 1 gives an idea of the unusual shape of the upper shell where the lid fits in.

This large tortoise is a smaller variety than the enormous Galapagos tortoises. The largest specimens are about 50=60cm (20=24ins) long. Land tortoises are vegetarians and live in the tropics where there is plenty of growth at ground level to feed on. As you can see, tortoises have no teeth, and use their sharp horny beak to cut grass or leaves which they swallow whole. Different races live in different parts of the world and sometimes on different islands. This skull may have been from the same specimen as record number S0520.

This large tortoise was the property of John Hancock, and may even be part of the same animal as specimen number S0518. The red marks on the top of the shell outline one of the shell bones, and the larger blue ones outline the position of the horny, or tortoishell scales, which have been removed. As you can see they are different sizes and in different places. The view of the under shell, or plastron, shows where the shell was cut away to remove the rest of the bones, and how it was wired back together afterwards. It also shows John Hancock's initials, which he used to write on his own specimens.

This turtle was collected by John Bartram in 1765 when exploring the Ohio River. He probably sent it to Marmaduke Tunstall whose Museum eventually came to be one of the very early acquisitions of the "Newcastle Museum" in 1822 (before its name was changed to the "Hancock Museum"). It is one of the oldest dated specimens in the Museum. Soft-shelled Turtles are covered with tough skin, often with some horny scales on the limbs. They also have spine-like tubes around the front edge of their shells. They are a fresh water species, only found in North America.

This Chameleon skeleton had been partially cleaned by insects when it was found. The small teeth teeth are used for gripping the insects caught by the long sticky tongue. At the back of the skull are the remains of the casque which gives Chameleons their distinctive outline.

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull no left quadrate, mandible in two halves.
NarNarrative: This is one of the large monitor lizards. The largest monitor, the Kemodo Dragon, can be dangerous to humans. They are all carnivorous, and as the picture shows, there are only a few sharp teeth at the front of the mouth for grasping prey and some very tough rounded ones at the back for crushing. These lizards swallow their food whole, or in pieces, and all the digesting is done in their internal organs. This is an Old World group which is not found in the UK.

These are rattles from the ends of the tails of two Rattlesnakes. The rattles are composed of the cast of the snake's skin which is carried at the end of the tail. When shaken it makes quite a lot of noise. One use suggested for it is to warn large animals that they might tread on it. Rattlesnakes are only found in the New World (South and North America).

This rare Crocodile inhabits a part of the world where alligators are more common than crocodiles; the main characteristic of crocodiles' skulls can be seen in this side view, where the fourth tooth from the front of the lower jaw fits into a notch outside the upper jaw, unlike alligators, in which this tooth fits into a notch in the jawbone itself.

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull missing most of teeth, plus loose teeth and quadrate pieces.
NarNarrative: The long, slender jaws of the Gharial, with two rows of pointed teeth, are typical of fish eating animals. Gharials are found only in the estuaries of the larger rivers of India and Burma. Unfortunately in our picture the upper and lower jaws are not quite aligned, so the teeth can't be seen locking together as they do in life.

This bone lies beneath the turtle's body. It is covered by the outer tortoiseshell plates. As you look at the picture, the turtle's head would be to the left, its tail to the right and it would be lying on its front, on top of these bones. Sea turtles have no need of solid bony shells as land tortoises do, because the water supports their bodies.

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull (in mounted skin). Mounted for display.
Skeleton. About the size of an adder, Viper berus.
NarNarrative: This skeleton has no information with it. If it comes from Britain it is probably an Adder. The bones are old and dirty, so that it is difficult to make out details in the picture, but the skull, at the left hand end, is definitely of one of the poisonous snakes in the Viper family.

NarNarrative: The picture shows the turtle's skull. In life the animal was protected by a covering of tiny bones, all locked together, beneath a tough leathery skin. The Leathery Turtle is the largest variety of the sea turtle group. This one was nine feet wide from flipper to flipper.
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Blyth (off the coast)
